Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Technically in the sense that there is no resurrection without the cross. But it is rarely referred to that way. The Orthodox Liturgy is about what hasn't even happened yet--the transfigured world. This is the entire meaning of iconography, to make the unseen real, and why it is part of our theology, not just pretty pictures. When you receive communion, you are receiving the transfigured Christ. Some people may argue the finer points and there may be some variation from region to region but it has been said many times about the two liturgies--one seems forever centred on Calvary; the other on Pascha. 

There is some parting of ways on the whole notion of atonement too, mostly a reaction to Anselm, but then, there are some Orthodox thinkers who think Anselm's ideas are correct. One thing for certain: you will always get lots of disagreement within the Orthodox church.

Comment: "the children used to light up cigarettes"? I'm Reform Jewish, I have cousins who are Orthodox Jewish, and I never heard of that.
"they have a holiday where they empty all the food from their homes". That's the Jewish holiday of Pesach, "Passover" in English. It celebrates the Exodus from Egypt. But, observant Jews don't get rid of all food. They only get rid of any product that has leavening (baking powder, yeast, etc.). They donate unopened products to charity, or give it to their neighbors or have the neighbors store it for eight days, etc.
There are, indeed, very few places in Denver to get high-quality fresh Kosher meat and poultry. Partly it's because, from the standpoint of the Jewish community, Denver is an isolated spot. Denver probably has one of the largest Jewish communities between the Mississippi River and California. There are other factors as well.

Comment: It has been said that the 2 degree limit is an aspiration , not a binding target with penalties, so while not dismissing it , there is no way that it is going to happen under the current system of controls. There  has been quite a bit written on future oil use, and there seems to be general consensus that oil will be the major fuel source beyond 2040. The innovation to something new to replace oil has been thrown around for more then two decades, primarily be environmentalists but also by governments as well. We haven't found anything yet, and it's not as if there hasn't been an effort, because as people have said this would be a world game changer. However we can't discard what we have, on the hope that we will find something to replace oil. The authors don't break new ground here, but rather put forth many of the same arguments that have been made before. those who agree. still agree, and those against still are, but they are becoming increasingly marginalized.

Comment: NPS has had its budget repeatedly slashed. It's really a wonder there are rangers at all to respond to a report of a bicycle abandoned by the side of the road. When rangers arrived they likely saw no signs of a struggle and assumed the rider had gone down to the river. An initial search revealed disturbed moss on rocks that suggested he might have fallen in. They likely yelled in all directions, hoping for a response. Absent that they really had no basis to call in a search. The subject could have gone up or down river, on this side or that, or simply bushwhacked back indirectly to his bike. If they hadn't picked up his gear and somebody else had the park might have been charged with negligence as well, and as long as they had his gear they knew they'd be the first people he'd contact. 
It really is a thankless job, and relies on a few, underpaid people who are dedicated to protecting the park. Want better? Stop the wars. 53% of your taxes goes to the military. Nothing left for peace.

Comment: The marines stopped at the Yalu, and at that point MacArthur had defeated the North Korean army. But the Chinese Liberation Army, far more numerous than the UN forces, launched a somewhat sneak attack on the UN forces, and the marines had to walk back in the middle of winter. MacArthur then wanted to drop nukes on China, but Truman wouldn't let him, as this would have led to a wider war with unpredictable consequences, but likely dragging in the USSR, which supplied arms to the Chinese and the North Koreans. Most notably T-34 tanks and MIG fighters with swept-back wings, which the USAF didn't have until later in the war. Some of the MIGs were flown by Russian pilots. Subsequently the UN forces were forced to retreat and North Korea was reestablished as a communist state, with Chinese support. So, the US was not in a position to cross into China, short of nuclear war. 
The stalemate continues and isn't going to end anytime soon, while the Chinese military gets stronger by the day.

Even if something works in San Francisco or Chicago, Denver is at a higher altitude, with less precipitation and humidity with higher daytime temperatures and lower night time temperatures. That means that there will be some reduction in water to move downstream.  This value should be estimated for the public to know. There should be a comparison of energy differences between solar panels and green roofs (perhaps a paper for you and the Botanic garden).
The issue is if the public is to make a significant fiscal decision it should be based on sound data.

Comment: Several years ago, the Manitoba Municipal Board has approved a water and sewer system in Elma, Manitoba. 

The board altered how residents will pay for the 4.2 million dollar project. Instead of an identical flat fee for ALL residents, the board ordered that the project be paid according to the assessed value of each property.  The cost is expected to range from 23 to 43 thousand dollars per homeowner over 20 years. 

Elma has been under a boil water advisory since 2004 because of a contaminated aquifer.

How much are First Nations paying toward the cost for clean drinking water as us "privileged settlers" pay toward ?

Comment: @J. K. Galbraith:

I think your point is fair. The scale of these enterprises is massive and requires expertise in order to work. Nonetheless, many people won't accept that, and I have seen that affect donations. 

I have specifically turned down a position in this sector - a dream job, really - because I didn't want to be branded as someone "earning six figures from a charity". The irony is that my present job in the private sector earns me way more than I would have in that role (or when I worked in the public sector), while requiring that I do LESS work. These experiences - and experiences shared from friends with both public and private sector experience - are why I always roll my eyes when people talk about the exorbitant wages in the public sector. Speaking diplomatically, both sectors have their issues.

Comment: Just putting it out there: The first one of any of these candidates that gets their act together and comes up with a comprehensive vision of what they see Hawaii's future to be will be the first person that would show real leadership going into this race. If the candidates just point their fingers at the "other guy" and say "I can be a better leader than him/her", than to me the voters should call out those candidates and say "do better."

We've done it before, and candidates have risen to the challenge and made their points known clearly. Jack Burns did it in 1970 Vs. Tom Gill.  Fasi did it enough in 1994 to beat the Republican candidate at the time, Pat Saiki (yeah, he lost, but still). And Lingle was able to cohesively put a vision in people's heads in 1998 and 2002, winning in the latter. That is what the voters wanted and that is what they were attracted by. 

Will the voters ask for it again? Lets see.

Comment: There are lots of factors that contribute to the hotter fires.  There has always been some fire suppression but when there are houses that suppression is increased so more fuel can accumulate to make hotter fires.  It is also getting hotter and drier which adds to the problem.
My grandfather built a little cabin in one of these transition zones about 0ne hundred years ago.  When people started living there year round the ecology changed rapidly.  Part of the reason people started living there year round was because there was not a much snow in the winter so they could.
Ventilation is a key when the wind blows a thousand degree fire along with windows and siding. It would be best not to build in these areas because to the ecology but if it is allowed code should look at more than little fires.

Comment: It appears that the people who outright reject multiculturalism and the population growth that is largely a result of it, as Ibbitson points out, either don't understand the economic necessity of increasing the population, or choose to ignore the facts. First of all, a small population does not in any way mean that people will be more prosperous or that the economy will be stronger. In fact the opposite is true.  The United States with ten times the Canadian population has the strongest economy in the world, so that theory is easily debunked. 
Secondly, Canadians no longer have large families by choice. Fifty years ago, it was not unusual for couples to have between eight and fourteen children, especially in Quebec. But as women became educated and chose to enter the workforce, they no longer wanted large families. So immigration is the only way to increase the population. 
And increase it, we must to retain the taxpayers' base necessary to sustain the social programs Canadians want.

Comment: Any illusion that NAFTA is a tri-national free trade association ends if Canada and the US proceed in the manner described in this article.  In its place will be the US with two binational free trade agreements, each with much smaller economies and both agreements roughly stitched together.  This is not the way to manage trade and development covering North America; especially for Canada and Mexico.

If the US (with a complicit Canada) essentially dictates terms to a weakened Mexico, Canada becomes isolated and has a hostile Mexico.  The revised NAFTA (or whatever the new post current NAFTA interlocking set of agreements is called) would lack a necessary basis of goodwill between its 3 partners to function adequately and the supply chains linking companies and industries in Canada to Mexico will be subject unduly complex and tenuous administration and protection.

Further, when the Trump administration later makes unreasonable demands on Canada, Canada will face this threat alone.

Comment: The notion that buying spin-offs is a value play is false.  Value investing requires an understanding of the underpinnings of the business, including management.  This is patently impossible in this scenario.

Spin-offs are capital market imbalances that can have edge for investors set up to buy them.  They fall in the same category as shorting firms that split their stocks, participating in large block trades to change ownership structures (think Nissan-Renault) and a handful  of others.

A far better approach is to view markets in a 3 dimensional way:
 1.) the Chicago price, that is fair value;
 2.) the supply and demand factors, who are the owners, sellers, buyers, what has changed (the above falls in this category); and 
3.) The price statistics. Looking at where prices trade over time relative to fair value.  If a stock is always cheap, it is a value trap.

Investing is much more complex than you suggest and the real story of value is much more nuanced and inaccessible to retail.

Comment: "Rising ocean temperatures and increasing levels of ocean acidity — carbon dioxide absorbed as carbonic acid — are currently having devastating effects on ocean ecosystems."  Joe Sheldon, PhD

"On the pH scale, which runs from 0 to 14, solutions with low numbers are considered acidic and those with higher numbers are basic. Seven is neutral. Over the past 300 million years, ocean pH has been slightly basic, averaging about 8.2. Today, it is around 8.1, a drop of 0.1 pH units, representing a 25-percent increase in acidity over the past two centuries."  National Geographic

Notice that the average is 8.2 therefore, we can conclude that the ocean pH over the past 300 million years has been higher or lower than the average.  Notice that 7 is neutral therefore, anything less than 7 is more acidic.

Lions, tigers, and bears oh my!  Chicken Little describes it best, "The Sky is falling!"

Comment: The fact that you erroneously believe marijuana for recreational use has already been legalized in Canada (it hasn't) probably helps explain why you have little awareness that such legalization has been a political issue since the early 1970s. 

The LeDain Commission in 1972,  the Senate Special Committee on Illegal Drugs in 2002 and the House of Commons Special Committee on the Non-Medical Use of Drugs in 2002 were all formal political processes exploring the need to regulate rather than criminalize the use of marijuana for recreational use. As well, there were two bills introduced to decriminalize marijuana - 2003 (Chrétien) and 2004 (Martin) - only to have the legislation die because parliament was prorogued and the Martin's government fell.  Such processes reflect a shift in social norms regarding such use with the majority of people recognizing the folly of criminalization. 

So your view is your view, but it is not a view informed by political history of the issue.

9  A person must not

Comment: Clearly they offered him a job for stepping aside. Whether that is a crime or not, was up to the judge to decide and it seems that he did not think it was a criminal offence. End of story........except that this is a great example of what is wrong with our current electoral system. 
The basis of a parliamentary democracy used to be that candidates (all parties) were elected by the membership of that party in their riding. If elected, that candidate would be expected in part to champion the interests of  those in the riding. 
Today it seems that candidates are either appointed by the party or are elected as a result of mass last minute sign ups of new members - worryingly, in many cases those new members often being signed up on the basis of their race or religion to support a candidate of their same race or religion.  
We don’t need to change our electoral system - simply to restore the current one to working order.

Comment: The Church asserts:
Everyone knows that the Fathers of the Church laid down the duty of the rich toward the poor in no uncertain terms. As St. Ambrose put it: "You are not making a gift of what is yours to the poor man, but you are giving him back what is his. You have been appropriating things that are meant to be for the common use of everyone. The earth belongs to everyone, not to the rich."[2]
— Pope Paul VI, Populorum Progressio (1967)

I lifted the above from the Wikipedia entry "Universal destination of goods." The universal destination of goods is a foundational principle in Catholic teaching; the right to private property is subservient to it.  Populorum Progressio is as relevant and important today as it was fifty years ago.

Comment: This Is The Inside Of Trump’s Lawyer’s Passport
https://www.buzzfeed.com/anthonycormier/trumps-lawyer-showed-you-the-cover-of-his-passport-heres
"once to Italy in July. The Italian trip is the most intriguing, because it places Cohen in what’s known as the Schengen Area: a group of 26 European countries, including the Czech Republic, that allows visitors to travel freely among them without getting any additional passport stamps.
.
Upon entering the Schengen Area, visitors get a rectangular stamp with the date, a country code, their port of entry, and a symbol showing how they entered — such as an airplane or a train. In Cohen’s passport, that mark appears on page 17, with a date of July 9. The mark is too faint to be fully legible. Comment: Bottled water is one of the most wasteful habits this country has. In a time of cheap oil, plastic bottles aren't recycled but end up in landfills or cast into the environment. Even in times when it is more expensive, less than 40% of these billions of single usage bottles are ever recycled. That's a huge amount of wasted plastic. Combine that with the energy it takes to transport water at seven pounds per gallon, distances of thousands miles(Fiji water actually comes all the way from Fiji!) and we waste vast resources and create a huge amount of solid waste. It is also ridiculous to spend five dollars a gallon on water  which is usually the same quality that can be purchased locally for around twenty dollars for a thousand gallons. Buy inexpensive reusable bottles, fill them from the tap. If you are concerned for some reason about water quality, buy a water filter. Over the years, you will save thousands of dollars and do your part to reduce waste and pollution.

Comment: Often times the creation of these 'open' work areas comes down to a matter of economics. That's simply the truth, no matter how it's sugar-coated otherwise. In the end, although employers may save money on the front end (skipping the costs associated with more personal work areas) they pay dearly on the back end when it comes to the matter of productivity.

I spent the better part of the past 5 years in an 'open' work area. Management gave us bare bones accommodation (think tables pushed together) and yet complained when people talked all day. It's like they didn't get it. I've recently moved to a new company and I'm back to the 6 foot high walls of my own personal cubicle. While I'm a very adaptable person and can work in a variety of office space types, there can be no question that I'm much more productive when I have my own personal work space. You shouldn't have to be a rocket scientist to get this. Sadly, many employers don't get it still.

Comment: Look beyond the Hawaii longline fleet to understand bigeye overfishing. The United States longline fleet accounts for only 10% of the total longline catch of bigeye. Furthermore, the total longline catch is less than half of the total bigeye catch. Over half of the catch is juvenile individuals taken as incidental catch by the enormous and still growing purse seine fishery. Bigeye are thus vulnerable to fishing through their entire life cycle. Catches by both the purse seine and the longline fleet must be curtailed in order to recover bigeye stocks. Unfortunatly, the Western and Central Pacific Fishery Commission seems incapable creating meaningful constraints of the purse seine fishery. Meanwhile longline quotas for bigeye are being steadily ratcheting downward providing incentive to find means to finesse the quotas.

Comment: @Christine Cameron-Drew, re: "suggestion as an alternative to water?" - I think water is best, suitably modified. Nitro is past its 'use by', I personally knew some who used nuclear, it didn't do what was required. The Canadians are trying gelled propane, some use carbon dioxide, but modified water is my favourite. That is all in sandstone & shale, acid is used to etch carbonates in lieu of proppants. 

It is all in accord with Darcy's Law for flow in permeable media - the flow rate is proportional to the drive pressure & inversely proportional to the flow distance & permeability. Drive energy is a given {water injection apart}, permeability cannot be altered, except by acid in the very near-wellbore area, so stimulation is done by changing the flow regime from radial to parallel flow, reducing the distance the fluid needs to travel.

Comment: Wrong again DD ! The ONLY US Constitutional process for making international agreements is by treaty between the lawful governments of the nations. International treaties are required to be ratified by Congress. The US congress rejected the ratification of the Hawaii Annexation Treaty of 1897 based on two main factors.

the first reason the US Congress rejected the ratification of the Hawaii Annexation Treaty was in accordance with the customary international legal principle that nations cannot annex one another. This is to prevent powerful nations like Germany in the case of Czechoslovakia and Russia in the case of Eastern Ukraine, from taking over smaller countries,

The second reason is that a great majority of Hawaiian subjects rejected the idea of annexation by signing the ku'e petitions and submitting them to the US Congress.

There was also the question of the legitimacy of the Republic of Hawaii since it was an unelected government which directly resulted from a coup d'etat.

Comment: Such a horribly misleading piece.  1,400 page  "intimidating" document? Why is it intimidating, because it has facts and analysis? Any less the Navy would be accused of not preparing enough.  The Navy modeling methodology has been the federal standard for decades - used by FAA and DoD - and courts have universally found it lawful AND reliable.  AND the EIS does have noise levels for individual events, sometimes over 100 dB.  Measurements only tell you how loud it is at the one spot, on that day with those atmospherics, it does not predict noise for aircraft not there and how noise propagates.  AND we already know the Growler is loud, so what is the measurement supposed to tell us that we don't already know? the measurement argument is just a red herring.  And as for your completely speculative swipe at the "data," you have nothing to base that on - have you even read the DEIS?  That data is in an appendix.  Don't debase yourself my lying.

Comment: No, I'm describing the reasons why health care costs too much.

A doctor visit, a mammogram or a papsmear, a blood test, a prostate exam, a birth control prescription, even a normal childbirth.... these are all routine, budgetable, affordable health care procedures that don't need to be "insured" because we know about how much they're going to cost, and we can work them into our budget.  But that $30 birth control prescripition requires a doctor visit every six months (why?), and each time it's filled, the doctor's office has to process a claim, the pharmacy has to process a claim, and the insurnace company has to process the same claim, then the doctors office and pharmacy have to keep track of reimbursements and follow up when they don't get paid. The claims processing costs associated with that $30 birth control add over $300 worth of labor costs to those pills, simply for claims process.  And those costs are part of your premiums.  Totally unnecessary.

Comment: I have to laugh at Mr. Eastburn's saying the civilian assault rifles look "little different" then a semi-auto hunting rifle. They look a lot different, in fact, what they look like are military assault rifles and carbines, and their purpose isn't for hunting, it is for "big boys" to "play war" with. The AR-15 was the progenitor of the M-16 and M-4, and they are identical in operation except for selective fire, they have similar high-capacity quick replace magazines, the same deadly power and accuracy, and the same capability to kill many people in a very short time.

Semi-auto hunting rifles in most states are limited to 5 shots before reloading, and seldom are more needed.

We call those Cabela's military style rifles "civilian assault rifles" because they are primarily owned by civilians, and they are the weapon of choice for assaults upon multiple civilians. If it looks like a duck and it shoots like a duck, it probably is a duck.

Comment: The signature itself is not the issue unless it is blank.  The form requires the last four digits of the social security number, printed name of voter, voter signature, address of voter, and voters date of birth including the year.  Common reasons a signature is invalid is that the person is not registered at the address listed, the person did not include the four digits of the social security number, or the complete date of birth, or simply left something blank.  Once the Office of elections checks these things they should be okay.  However, they can be challenged up until the 14th of June this year.  The whole thing is a mess in my opinion.

Comment: The John Paul II argued that in a "culture of death" it was morally contradictory to execute murders was because the murder of children in their mother's wombs was sanctioned. However, he never claimed capital punishment was "against the Gospel", which it demonstrably isn't, and, therefore, intrinsically evil. He recognised it was a matter for the prudential judgement of civil authority. John Paul thought that capital punishment was in practice best avoided but this was a non-binding prudential judgment.

Pope Francis cannot  reverse Scripture or his predecessors on such a matters. He is bound to binding interpretations. There a mountain of evidence from Scripture, the Fathers and Doctors of the Church, Popes, Saints and theologians, and Catechisms and other Church documents, that shows conclusively the legitimacy of capital punishment. 

And since you ask, I am against personally against the death penalty for the reasons given by John Paul and not Pope Francis.

Comment: In a world of 7 billion humans, headed for 9 billion by 2050 and 12 billion by 2100, it would be an interesting debate regarding which constitutes the greatest existential threat to humanity: resource development or overpopulation. Interesting, but short.

Canadian eco screamers can wail and lament all day long about hypothetical, and perhaps even occasionally accurate climate change prognostications, but the approaching train coming at us from out of the tunnel is fuelled by our own "fruitfulness".

And there is no doubt about the population numbers, none at all. Short of an extinction event, those numbers are going to happen. "Deniers" need not apply.

Dealing with a  few centimeters of sea level rise will seem like a walk in the park.

The world will demand, and try to force, that nations like Canada and Australia must accept not a few million, but tens or even hundreds of millions of these global citizens.

What will we do? What should we do? What could we do?

Comment: Oddly, Johnson omits one of the most obvious things women can do: intelligent self-defense.  God knows I'm no expert, but I would imagine that women can prepare themselves to react suitably in all sorts of situations, ranging from "Get off me, you creep!" in the crowded subway car to using a weapon they've been trained to use.  I've encountered on the internet a document purporting to summarize the advice of convicted sexual assaulters to women wanting to avoid danger.  Whether it's genuine or not, a lot of it made intuitive sense--long hair makes you a more likely target, bulky clothing makes you less likely, carrying anything that can be used as a weapon, like an umbrella, discourages attackers, etc.  

The really tough problems are in the villages.  A drunken assaulter can be orders of magnitude more dangerous than a sober one.  And it's an undeniable fact that the victims are often drunk themselves.  

No, women shouldn't have to defend themselves.  But they do.

Comment: My point to prima facie is, even if the US Congress approves a treaty, we are "subjecting" ourselves to another country, which is prima's complaint.
No nation can just simply go it alone, and tell other countries "you go to Hell!" Not even us.
Yes, in a lot of ways, the Paris accord is symbolic, but it put us on record as a) acknowledging that anthropogenic global warming is real, b) that we were publicly committed to reducing carbon emissions, and, most importantly, c) by doing so, we hope other nations do the same.
Trump just threw c) out the window.
If anthropogenic global warming is real -- and I strongly believe it is -- then telling the world "you all can reduce carbon emissions if you want, but we'll drill, baby, drill, and burn coal as we darn well please" is a great way for other countries to do the same, and we can all watch our coastal cities slowly flood as we sit and point fingers and yeall "no, you go first!"
Except this generation will be dead by then, so why worry?

Comment: "Just hollow words to you eh?"

Exactly.  I treat all beliefs equally -- using the scientific method.  The hypothesis that governments require "consent of the governed" is actually a testable hypothesis.  It's demonstrably false. But even using America, or literally any country on the planet, I can demonstrate that it isn't consensual.  Governments have always existed, long before "consent of the governed" was ever thought of.

Government is force.  Tihs is just a plain fact.  If it's government, it's not consensual by definition.  If there is no force involved, then it's not a real government.  "Consent of the governed" is an oxy-moron.  It would be like saying "consent of the rape victim" because we took a vote and gave the rapist the "right" to rape his victim and called that consent.  Logically absurd.

Comment: There is no such thing as indigenous people in America.  Mammals lived in North America for over 100 million years before the first humans came here, around 15,000 years ago after a long migration from eastern China and Siberia.   There are thus no humans that are native to North America.  Human life did not originate here.   We are all the exact same species: Homo Sapiens.   The only difference between all of us is when we arrived here, and the minor genetic differences between us.

Comment: There is ample history of the world not taking the threats of maniacal despots at face value and living to regret it. That could be happening with Kim Jong Un.

On the surface Western governments appear sanguine in the wake of increasingly strident pronouncements from North Korea that it intends to wipe Japan and the U.S. off the face of the earth. The threats are largely dismissed as posturing and sabre-rattling - more for the benefit for the brainwashed at home than enemies abroad.

Intelligence agencies aren't convinced Kim has a viable nuclear warhead that can be accurately, reliably delivered to his intended targets. But if he doesn't have it yet, they are confident he will in the next 12 to 18 months. Which places its neighbours and their sworn protector in a quandary. 

A pre-emptive strike might conceivably halt the nuclearization of North Korea and neutralize Kim. It could also unleash a flurry of conventional weapons that might kill many thousands on either side of the DMZ.

Comment: So here is the crux of what this story is all about:

The Board is going to consider the guaranteed rate of return to the PERS employees and employers.  The guess at the rate of return is how much to credit to each account.  If there is too much money,  from good investments and markets,  the employees get the overage,  or have in the past.  If the rate of return does not make the estimated return,  the taxpayers via public employers,  all of which are tax supported,  have to pony up the difference between the expectation and the reality.  Damned if you do,  and damned if you don't.

So the jackboots of public employee unions and lawyers are stepping hard in the throats of every citizen of Oregon,  on behalf of a small minority that got a windfall two decades ago,  with overheated markets,  and when those crashes occurred,  continued to believe a windfall every year was their entitlement.   Now we watch daily as our all millionaire Congressional delegation demands the same for ACA.

Comment: They certainly have postulated runaway AGW. I hear it constantly. Consensus is not science. Science is about prediction, not straw polls. If a science cannot predict then it is useless, regardless of the consensus. Consensus is usually anti-science. 1000 years ago, the consensus was that the sun orbited the earth. I don't think many deny that CO^2 will lead to or is at least correlated with rising temps. It's the hypothesized feed-backs that amplify the predicted increases up to 4x (4 degrees v 1 degree) that are the points of contention. The feed-backs are not observed and the models have repeatedly failed to predict. Regardless, even if it was warming 1 degree or even 3 degrees by 2100, what should we do about it? De-industrialize? The human suffering and cost associated with that course would vastly exceed any benefit of lowering temps. Historically, warmer periods are beneficial to humans and expand the biomass of the earth.

FAMILIES - What are you telling you children about STEM?

Comment: Ken, you're a brave man to call it like it is.

Jonsen may never make it as a starter: six sacks and one pick, though another was a gimme that was dropped. I've heard more than one coach say you can teach a lot but making good decisions is the hardest skill: it seems a lot of that is innate QB IQ. Wilson appeared to me to be the future. He had that "x" factor that jumps out: a quickness that cannot be learned. A "live" arm from which the ball appears to rocket. Quickness, not just straight-line speed--- overall rapidity in all action.
Of course, if Hoke's D indeed takes major, major steps to the point of being Stanford-like---- it could be an interesting year. The key will be in limiting offensive errors and not giving up bunches of throwing scores

Comment: I quit my placer mines because I couldn't work the proven rich benches and pipes (localized ore deposits) just 200 feet away from the creek, because giant, out-of-state mining companies had filed on all of the land surrounding my 20 claims.  That was over 30 years ago, and checking recently, those mining companies haven't done anything since, except perform annual labor.
My tiny 20 claims was probably a good piece of several peoples yearly pay-checks, because I bought equipment, fuel, supplies, paid for repairs, and etc.  Before the mid-80's, there were many hundreds of us "small" placer operations, all making and spending money.  The giant out-of-state mining companies squashed us flat.  But they don't spend even a hundredth of the money we spent in Alaska's economy. Comment: An excellent analysis by the professor and his student, but it may have underplayed the role that wood plays as a sustainable source of energy to meet Canada's many and varied demands.  

Natural resources Canada estimates that the industrial sector gets about 11% of its energy from burning waste wood as well as left-over pulping liquors from the pulp and paper sector while generating a paltry 0.2% of the greenhouse gas emissions of the sector.  A 2011 study by the Government of BC estimated that the forest industry in BC produces more that $640 million worth of energy from waste wood residues that is not likely reported in official stats.  Similarly, households get 11% of their energy from wood.

For data see:
http://oee.nrcan.gc.ca/corporate/statistics/neud/dpa/showTable.cfm?type=HB&sector=agg&juris=00&rn=1&page=0d 
http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0961953414004036

Comment: Stock (who is, in any event, vastly superior to her opponent) doesn't ask the harder question: can we--Alaska--really do anything significant about slowing climate change?  

The answer is obviously no: global carbon emissions will not be detectably lower because Alaskans put up a few hundred, or even a few thousand, wind generators.  Hell, if Alaska went entirely carbon-free overnight, it would be years, more likely decades, before that difference alone would be noticed--and that's assuming everything else stayed the same, which it obviously wouldn't.  You'd have to take a lot of carbon out of the air to stop seas from rising.

So, Margaret, even if Alaska's Three Stooges are wickedly refusing to face the facts and admit the problem, what difference does that make to Alaska?  What are we going to do differently if you're elected?--to reduce Alaska's carbon output in ways that will actually contribute to global reduction?

Comment: You have to read through an awful lot of this article to get to the truth about Finney's eviction.  The house has mold problems, that she herself reported and wanted fixed. Comment: Hi Andrew,  Thank you so much for telling us about your Dad. Too often in this world we operate with little or no knowledge of the trials and challenges that people have experienced. Many years ago, around 1982 I think I met your Dad when I was a sales person selling the Predictive Index.  I used to cold call executives with the goal of setting up an appointment.  Day in and day out these very brusque captains of industry would give me short shrift and often hang up the phone.  Your Dad on the other hand was very patient and courtly in an almost old world way.  Over time I got to meet him a number of times and to this day remember him as a great gentleman.  He was very kind and did not exhibit the big ego that is common to business people at that level.  The world would be a better place with more people like him!

Comment: Rick - I want to inform you that your information about me is incorrect.  I do not presently own any two bus company in Waikiki.  From 1974 until 1995 I was part-owner of E Noa Tours and the Waikiki Trolley (I am happy to say the company is still very active in its 42nd year).  We were a regulated Common Carrier of passengers by the State PUC.  We carried over 1 million people per year, and we had over 50 vehicles and 100 drivers. Ridership was the lifeblood of a private company like E Noa.  I have brought the topic of rail ridership to the attention of the city council.  Low ridership will kill this project.  The majority of rail riders (according to HART) will come from the bus - that is, they will be forced to transfer to rail (their bus routes will be changed to become "Feeder" routes for rail).  Our current mayor has never discussed this fact with the public including our bus riders.  He is misleading us by omitting this fact.

Comment: The batteries supply all my night time needs.  I own a Leaf: yep I don't pay for electricity or gas. The system cost $18K.  Once I've used all the tax credits it will be a net out-of-pocket of about $6K.  However I didn't pay for the batteries.  Sunrun gave them to me for free because they used me as a guinea-pig: mine was the first house in the western hemisphere to have the Powerwall installed and there were many teething issues to work through with HECO and the city.  Had I paid for the batteries I think it would have added about $7K to the gross cost of the system (before calculating tax breaks).  There was one issue: we discovered that the batteries export in series, not in parallel, so even when fully charged they need an assist from the grid at night to deliver the power needed to charge the Leaf.  Sunrun is going to upgrade  to take care of that problem.  I learned to program my Leaf after sun-up and learning to do laundry and dishwashing at night to avoid draining batteries.

Comment: I think the issue here is a question: what is the difference between a humane approach to complex issues and an endorsement of the status quo? I don't think any one side is responsible for all the fear. I think "fear" is what we call the other side's insistence on their own positions. The underlying problem is, the gospel often gives us guidelines, not specific answers to specific issues.

Comment: A friend observes that in Chinese history, when the power of the emperor is exercised by someone else, and the real emperor is only a "puppet emperor", that marks not just the marginalization of the emperor but the beginning of the end of the dynasty. Obviously, the parallels are inexact. But we should not miss the significance of the fact that the power of the presidency is now being exercised by a surrogate who has embraced frankly racist and anti-Semitic views. Our "experiment" in democratic self-government is relatively new in the long history of the world; there is no guarantee that it will survive. In the run up to the election and to the inauguration of Trump, I expressed several times my confidence that our Constitution and institutions are strong enough to survive his presidency. I still believe that; but I have been stunned by emergence of a neo-Nazi as the de facto president. Every day that Donald Trump is president, the presidency is demeaned and the country is diminished.

Comment: Depending on what our federal government will do, the CBC subsidy this year might be in the $1.1 to1.5 billion range.  Using a Canadian population of 36 million, and a subsidy of $1.1 billion, that is about $30.50 per Canadian. The population served by our local newspaper is about 30,000. This means this population contributes $915,000 per year to CBC. The TOTAL revenue of local newspaper and radio stations in this region is probably just over $2.25 million per year and they are bravely operating, giving us lots of local news, opinion, and entertainment. For the money given to CBC, we get a few news stories about big city accidents and some events, weather, no news or opinions about our own local governments and events, but some news and opinions nationally. Which is the better deal?

Comment: The 2014 peer-reviewed study by Jesse Richman and others, estimated that from 38,000 to 2.8 million non-citizens voted illegally in the 2008 presidential election with a point estimate of about 1.2 million, meaning about 6.4% of non-citizens voted in the election.
https://ww2.odu.edu/~jrichman/NonCitizenVote.pdf
Critics of this study have decried the very small sample of declared non- citizens on which it is based, 339, about 1% of the sample, without noting that since 4% of the US population are non-citizens, it is likely that many of the respondents who truthfully declared that they voted untruthfully declared that they were citizens. Incredibly, the main criticism of the study’s conclusions take the opposite tack, that in this already undersized sample of non-citizens, most or all who said they voted were actually non-citizens, falsely indicating that they had committed a felony, when actually they hadn’t. You couldn’t make this stuff up and have anyone believe you!

Comment: As far as I'm aware the only "low standard" country with a FTA with Canada is Mexico through NAFTA.   Our trade deficit with Mexico in 2015 was about $10B, which was roughly equal to our deficit with Germany, a so called "high standard" country.   People who criticize free trade with "low standard" countries forget about the benefits from that trade.  How many articles of clothing does the average Canadian have with a Made in Canada label?  Why is that so?  

A more likely source of manufacturing job loss is technology that has been employed to reduce labour costs and improve productivity.  My business (mining) has seen a technological revolution over the last 40 years that reduced the workforce several fold while actually increasing metal output.  Similar stories can be found in other businesses.  Look at the number of employee hours required to build an auto and compare it to 40 years ago.

Comment: " ..Rising house prices make people wealthier on paper,.."
Well - no ! You need a place to live, and in that sense you are not getting "wealthier" merely by staying in the market.
The focus on the likes of Toronto or Vancouver is quite misleading, nobody is forcing people - young, old, immigrant - to live there. There are many smaller cities where housing costs remain reasonable in an environmetn of low traffic congestion, clean air and still all the facilities ( e.g. "shopping"  .-). Takes a bit of strategic planning - by way of example I had a challenging professional career, always lived in a rural environment and my normalized housing costs were about 1/2 of the likes of "Toronto"( been there ). Never mind an easy commute, clear skies and park like environment.
A second thought - the Mc Mansions of today are of far better quality, huge by comparison to housing say 50 years ago. Anything over 1000 - 1500 square feet is a waste of space, not knocking it but not necessary.

Comment: In Canada, at least, the Criminal Code crime of terrorist activity does not require there be a group involved - it's a matter of motivation and intention.

Here's the basic definition of "terrorist activity" in the Code:

"s. 83.01 (b) an act or omission, in or outside Canada,
    (i) that is committed
        (A) in whole or in part for a political, religious or ideological purpose, objective or cause, and
        (B) in whole or in part with the intention of intimidating the public, or a segment of the public, with regard to its security..."

Sounds like a fair description of what we've learned so far.  And it appears that English law might be similar, since it's been reported that he was arrested for a terror offence.

Comment: Your emission per unit volume numbers are a little off. A $50/tonne CO2 tax adds about 11.5 cents/liter for gasoline, 13.5 cents/liter for diesel, and 9.5 cents/cubic meter for natural gas.

Comment: I think you are wrong and would suggest you go look at the statistics. With the exception of rollovers I doubt there is much difference to the passenger cell in a standard accident and even rollovers aren't as bad as you would think. A friend rolled his Ford Explorer and the roof compacted to the seat tops & dash while another buddy rolled his wife's MG and walked away with a broken nose, black eyes and aches and pains - no air bags.
Always wear those seat belts and snug them up tight.
Over 14 years in my Solara and not even a fender bender & I drive it all 12 months of the year. It is a great car in snow with the right tire and the soft top is probably better insulated than most steel lids & so I am always warm and toasty.
My only complaint would be chinook cross winds in the foothills of the Rockies - when they reach speeds of 100 km or greater the frameless windows are pulled out on the leeward side of the car and the noise is terrible. Luckily winds of that strength are rare.

Comment: They are talking about a lower yield this year.  It might help if they didn't leave a 35-40 mile long trail of onions laying along eastbound I-84 stretching from a few miles east of Arlington to Hermiston and beyond.  Every year when I travel to the Pendleton Round-Up  I see 1,000's of softball sized onions littering the median and shoulders of the freeway.  Every once in a while you pass a truck that has onions heaped 2-3 feet above the sides of the truck walls so they just end up rolling from the top and fall off.  It is kind of amusing when you see onions come bouncing and rolling into the rest areas near Boardman or Stanfield.  
On a slightly different note, along the westbound side of I-84 leaving Pendleton you will most likely find a very similar trail; however, it will be potatoes instead of onions.  I guess I will have to spend a little time this year and get a few pictures.

Comment: The reasoning is correct: Affordable Ag labor requires free housing. There are various issues to solve, however: A 'tiny' house has to still live up to a particular building code, which would have to be determined. Otherwise we end up with more blue tarp dwellings and waste problems. Any county permitted Ag labor housing has to still be approved by the Labor Department for being appropriate to their laws. Hefty fines threaten the farmer otherwise. Then there's the issue of how to prove to be a farmer--a tricky one indeed. Is it based on taxable farm income, farm size or production, years in business, etc? But the most crucial one would be enforcement, and that is the wildest card of all here in Hawaii.

Comment: Excellent article ! People in Alaska need to educate themselves more about heroin and other opioids because it is now a problem all over Alaska not just the big city of Anchorage. Sadly, in smaller communities and villages we do NOT have the treatment options that are available in Anchorage. Why should you care ? Because you never know when a family member or friend over doses or when the child of a friend, co-worker or realative over doses. Drug addiction is a very tough addiction to beat. Drug users can go undetected until a tragic over dose occurs. Often drug addicts resort to theft or prostitution in order to support their habit even if the once had good jobs or attended school because of the spiral downwards. Sometimes violence is involved either by the addict or the addict being victimized. There is a emotional reason to care as well as a financial cost/burden to the public. There are not enough experienced and well trained professionals who can  provide treat anywhere in Alaska.

Comment: "On CO2's impact on global warming (which began about 300 years ago), even the IPCC is lowering the estimates of its sensitivity."
CO₂ has always existed as a radiative forcing, it wasn't born as a "greenhouse" gas yesterday (or 300 years ago). However, the anthropogenically-sourced ~43% increase in the CO₂ mixing ratio was an abrupt departure from the millions-of-years period of stability before industrialization, and clearly began after that period, not 300 years ago. The highest rates of increase have occurred since the mid 20th century.
The ranges of ECS values given in the IPCC ARs have actually been remarkably consistent. 1 through 3 had the ranges as 1.5ºC-4.5ºC. The AR 4 slightly increased only the lower limit of the range to 2ºC-4.5ºC. The AR 5 brought the range back to that of ARs 1-3, at 1.5ºC-4.5ºC. Neither the IPCC, nor the scientific community, have absolved CO₂ as the dominant cause of modern warming.

Comment: OnTheIssues.org lists political positions of Congress members under various topic areas. 23 positions are listed for Gabbard under 19 topic areas or ~1 position per topic on average. For Sanders, excluding votes he's taken, over 400 positions are listed in 24 topics, or 19 positions per topic. For Warren (who's been in Congress as long as Gabbard) there are 119 positions in 24 topics or 5 positions per topic on average. These disparities indicate that if Gabbard were to be thought of as a progressive (which she cannot - see 1/3 above) she could only be called an EXTREMELY reluctant progressive. Those calling her a populist are right. She chooses popular stands on both liberal and conservative sides of different issues. She also has no ear or concern for her district. She has represented 3 non-overlapping constituencies, in 3 different levels of government, over 8 years, with little record and very few clear positions to show for it. Looks to me like she's an opportunistic populist. 3/3

Comment: '
The mandate is a Republican invention.
.

The idea of an individual mandate replacing the single-payer health care system was proposed in 1989 by the conservative Heritage Foundation and was published in a paper titled, “A National Health System for America.”
.
In the paper, the Heritage Foundation’s director of domestic policy strategies, Stuart M. Butler, proposed that “every resident of the U.S. must, by law, be enrolled in an adequate health care plan to cover major health care costs.”
.

Former Republican Senator John Chafee formally introduced the proposal in a 1993 bill titled, “Health Equity and Access Reform Today Act of 1993,” which had 20 Republican co-sponsors and included an individual mandate and vouchers for lower income individuals.
.
http://ivn.us/2013/09/27/obamacare-was-originally-proposed-by-republicans/

Comment: There is cultural component to whether or not diclectin is prescribed. I was pretty well incapacitated with nausea when pregnant but there was no mention of diclectin; I wasn't in Canada then and the drug wasn't used much where I was living. My second pregnancy was in Canada with the same nausea and immediately diclectin was recommended. I didn't take it as I knew it contained an antihistamine and would put me and the fetus to sleep. But I was surprised how commonly it was prescribed to Canadians.

I was interested to learn that my doctor, who was pregnant too and really struggling with nausea, didn't take it. 

Just recently there are studies suggesting the using antihistamines for three years or more can increase the chance of dementia in later years.  I have used them when not pregnant and now stay clear. Is this really a risk free drug for fetuses?

Comment: Living in the Copper Valley for 60 years I've found these hints: Dress in layers, but don't dress so warmly that you sweat. Wear moosehide mukluks with heavy felt insoles and thin socks under wool socks. Use a hat with a face-mask attached. Moose mitts on a harness with wool MITTENS inside. Gloves separate your fingers so they get cold. Use a scarf and try to breathe with your mouth closed so you aren't sucking that cold air into your lungs.
 To keep your place warm shovel snow up against the walls as high as you can. Close your curtains. Roll up a blanket or a rug and shove it up against the bottom of the door. Get some shrink wrap window kits and cover your windows. If there's cold air coming in through the electrical outlets put a piece of duct tape over them. Bring in a couple extra armloads of stovewood so you don't have to open the door and let the cold in. Be careful if you burn cottonwood, it gets SUPER hot. Leave just a tiny drip going from your faucet to prevent it freezing.

Comment: You may be aware that "idiot" used to have a clinical definition, and referred specifically to people with an IQ of 25 or lower. What you might not know is that many people with an IQ higher than 25 but lower than the normal range struggle to identify right or wrong in some contexts. 

Let's suppose your brother says John is bad and has threatened to hurt him, and asks you to kill John. As a person of presumably normal intelligence, we can count on you to reliably determine that killing John is not right in those circumstances. People with intellectual disabilities cannot always make that determination, and might easily decide doing what their brother asked was the right thing.

By the way, let's say you know John served time for several past murders, and you overheard a phone conversation in which he said he was going to kill your brother tonight. You have a chance to kill John and save your brother and get away with it. Is killing him right or is it wrong?

Comment: The RCMP are arresting and detaining them under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and turning them over to Canada Immigration for processing.

There is a very good legal reason why refugee claimants (not asylum seekers which are a completely different class of persons) are not being charged in respect of their entry to Canada.

Under Article 31 of the 1951 Convention on Refugees Canada has undertaken to not prosecute refugee claimants for illegal entry into Canada including any issues of false documents or fraud relating to that entry.

Canada has enacted that exemption into our domestic law as required by the Convention in various iterations of our immigration legislation over the years. Currently that exemption is contained at s. 133 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

So no charges because the law exempts refugees recognizing that refugees who are fleeing persecution are different from other migrants.

Then my father-in-law, also a WWII vet and POW, who is currently getting excellent care in the Alzheimers unit.  I've been getting my own treatment there for about ten years.  The wait times are long for non-emergency treatment, but the one time I needed them to, they got me in same day.  I've found the providers to be competent and conscientious, and friendly.  

I've heard the horrors stories, but they don't seem to apply to Denver.  Most of the problems with the VA have to do with the bureaucrats at the top.  The folks in the trenches are OK.

Comment: The U.S. tax code, and particularly the corporate income tax code, need a VAST overhaul.

The U.S. has the highest corporate tax rate in the developed world, yet manages to bring in far less revenue then many other countries.  Canada's Federal government brings in about 2.0% of GDP in corporate taxes with a Federal tax rate of 15% while the U.S. brings in only about 1.6% of GDP with a Federal tax rate of 35%.  Why?  Because their tax code is chalk full of special deductions, credits, exemptions, grants, etc. etc.

If the U.S. actually does eliminate 90%+ of their deductions, credits and the like they could easily bring in more revenue with a 15% tax rate than they do with their current 35% tax rate.  At the same time they would reduce compliance costs for companies and administrative costs for the government.

However they would lose the opportunity for politicians to pretend they are "doing something about the economy".

Comment: Undeclared, For all the bad mouthing of SB21 there has been no mention regarding the good that came of SB21. Before SB21 Anchorage and South Central were faced with impending Brown Outs because of depleted Cook Inlet natural gas. Because we incentivized drilling, major gas was found we are now exporting and Nikiski is booming again. South Central is now energy secure for many years to come. Also the Trans Alaska Pipe Line is running 1/4th full which creates operational problems. Not to mention the possibility of a possible shut down in the future. Less oil in pipe means less royalty money to fight over.

Comment: Call it whatever you want, but that's what allowing someone to pay a lower rate than someone else is.  Allowing someone to pay less than the normal % because they're poor is paramount to handing them a welfare check.  That's what welfare is -- special help for the poor that others don't get.

And I don't "argue with everybody", but I am willing to discuss the topic with those that don't understand what fair taxation is.  The fairest common tax we have is the sales tax -- a common rate for everyone.  If you can only afford to buy a little, you only pay a little tax.  If you can afford to buy a lot, you pay a lot of tax.  That's the beauty of percentages.  Same rate regardless of who you are.  As fair as it gets.

Comment: An understanding of the role of the SANDF in terms of its constitutional mandate is required before far fetched ideas of military detectives solving crime in the Cape are raised. 
Section 19.(1) of the Defence Act requires that the Defence Force may be employed in co-operation with the South African Police Service in terms of section 201(2)(a) of the Constitution in the prevention and combating of crime and maintenance and preservation of law and order within the Republic.
The President and Min of Defence and Police must specify where such deployments will occur plus other requirements of the Defence Act.
The SANDF may so deploy to the Cape Flats area but will do so based on an SAPS generated plan of operation with  CJOps operational inputs in respect of troop levels and possible tasks.
Those tasks would typically be assisting with cordons, protection of police road blocks and vehicle checkpoints plus combined patrols.  The police remain responsible for crime investigation.

Comment: Only a small fraction of the carbon in a forest is transferred to wood products. Different studies show that between 3-10 times  more carbon is transferred from forests to the atmosphere than is transferred to wood products. Also, wood products are not permanent. Studies show that they decay at about the same rate as dead wood in the forest. It does not matter how small the forest is, they all contribute to carbon storage if they are allowed to live and grow, or they contribute to global warming if they are logged and transferred to the atmosphere. The climate problem is one of cumulative effects. Every little bit counts. As Voltaire, once said, "No snowflake wants to be blamed for the avalanche."

Comment: Pippa Middleton is not a royal, she's not an almost-royal, she's not a quasi-royal.

She is someone who attended a school in England that brought her into contact with a lot of upper middle class and other privileged people.   Her sister happened to marry into the royal family.  There are people in the media who find this interesting spin great stories from everything they do.

The Queen, at the age of 91, is still doing over 250 public engagements per year meeting with people, listening to people and offering help when appropriate to her role.   Her schedule would exhaust people half her age.  She does things like visit people injured in the recent tragedy in Manchester.   A lot of these engagements are not covered in national UK publications, let alone international ones.  

Instead of promulgating misconceptions, it's worth considering who in the royal family does what how much and compare it to the non-royals who seek attention in the public eye.   It's an interesting exercise.

Comment: Only my comment here, so far?
Is Alaska oblivious to the possibility that these NSA attack tools could shut TAPS down at any moment, and in a way which would make restart extremely difficult?
I believe that there are valves designed to shut the flow off slowly, in case of a leak, as to not create a water hammer effect. If those valves were to be shut off quickly, the pipeline could burst somewhere upstream of each valve.
Are the people operating TAPS cognizant of the potential danger? Even if TAPS isn't hard-wired into the N. American fiber-optic system, there are still the satellite connections. And if the NSA attack tools have already infected TAPS, they could be set to trigger as soon as any remotely activated controls are taken off-line.
Were I in charge, I would immediately have all shut-off valves physically blocked from activating, except by manual override. That alone would prevent the worst of damage.
Then what about the smaller pipelines? The inlet platforms? What else?

Comment: I know the specifics of these situations vary, but one thing they each seem to have in common is that the shooter wants to make some sort of "statement." If we deny them the platform to do that, we might cut down on the motivations for these episodes.

There was an excellent article by Ari Schulman in the Wall Street Journal in November, 2013 about the phenomenon of the lone wolf mass killer and how to stop them, and this was his premise. We need to stop focusing so much attention on the perpetrators and, instead, place the focus on the victims, where it belongs.

In part, I blame the 24-hour news beast for this phenomenon. They plaster these killers' pictures on the screen and on the cover of People magazine and then drone on incessantly about who he was and why he did it. But we know that one reason he did it was precisely because he knew it would get that kind of attention. 

And you can bet that the next monster-in-waiting is taking it all in.

Comment: "In a world where our very existence is criminalized and our presence is defiance, Indigenous people are forced every day to live in a world built by their colonizers."

Perhaps the author doesn't realize that we're now in the 21st century. The notion that aboriginal existence is "criminalized" is so tangential as to come across to most Canadians as amounting to proof of a victim mentality. Sure, indigenous peoples were mistreated in the past, with "status Indians" being excluded from full citizenship and not being permitted to vote until 1960. And there's no doubt that indigenous peoples are forced to live in a world built by their colonizers. But this can be argued to be the case throughout most of the world, where Western influence has been pervasive for more than a century. It's not unique to Canada. Cloaking a community or culture in an eternal shroud of victimization isn't likely a healthy or productive basis on which to build a future.

Comment: The MLS average sales price is not to be trusted as a price indicator. The Teranet National Bank 11-city composite  HPI showed a 0.8% monthly decline in September, the first such decline since January 2016. Hamilton showed a 1.9% drop, its first monthly drop since February 2016, and Toronto a 2.7% drop, following on a 0.4% drop in August. There were also monthly declines in other Greater Golden Horseshoe cities not included in the composite index. We could be in the third month of a housing price correction for the GGH that might well take Canada into recession.

Comment: As several other posters have suggested already, the article's thesis seems fatuous:  As mass shootings can always be expected to induce terror, we can therefore suppose the inducement of terror to be inherent in the motivation of the crime, which renders pointless any attempt to distinguish one case from another in terms of motivation.   Well why stop there?  As death is invariably the result of homicide, why trouble ourselves with distinctions between spontaneous and premeditated, etc. -- the victims are equally dead in any case.  And what of 'hate crimes'?  Aren't those by definition determined by motivation?  In fact the law is continually making determinations of culpability and degree based on the motive of the offender.  So why try to claim here that it's irrelevant?  Other than as a dodge or damage control, that is.

Comment: Who paid for the $185,000 hip replacement? Not the insurance companies. We did. Does anyone believe a hip replacement should cost $185,000? Here are the costs as listed on the web for various countries. I checked with a few other sites and they agree to within 20%: 
On average, total hip replacements cost:
$6,757 in Spain
$7,685 in South Africa
$15,465 in New Zealand
$16,335 in the United Kingdom
$17,112 in Switzerland
$19,484 in Australia
$29,067 in the Unites States

Yet the story we're supposed to believe is that all the other civilized countries give you risky procedures and fake drugs. I agree, you will have to wait much longer in most countries. But can this explain the difference in cost?

The Church believes that "Nick" has a female soul, and hormones and surgery can not change it.

On the practical level, the Church has a lot to lose if it is pressured to adopt the "transgender hypothesis." Religious orders are sex-segregated, the most prestigious Catholic high schools are sex-segregated, youth ministry is often sex-segregated. In many parishes, even Bible Study is sex-segregated. (Paradoxically, many parishes have only a single restroom for mass-attenders, so this might end up being an easy one.)

Comment: Nothing:  The very topic of this story is process.  It is not about "content."  It requires an effective and fair procedure to address issues.  A cumbersome, awkward or unfair process precludes the effective consideration of issues.  If there are a number of specific items on a Council agenda, or a School Board agenda, or a Commissioners agenda, or whatever and wherever, those are the issues  publicly announced to be addressed at the meeting.  

If a public body provides for "public comment on non-agenda items" and two hours are spent listening to persons address anything they feel like addressing, the actual agenda issues will "suffer."  Of course, specific issues may be unique to specific jurisdictions.. That's why they're placed on the agenda.   "Reformatting public input or comparing it to JC won't solve Eugene's problems."  Of course not..  However, it might allow those issues to be addressed in a more efficient and effective manner for the council AND citizens.  Gary Crum
